author: By Reid J. Epstein and Jazmine Ulloa
title: As Hunter Biden Saga Endures, Democrats Avert Eyes and Dismiss Worries
description: After a setback for President Biden, Democrats pointed to Donald Trump’s indictments and suggested that swing voters would ultimately not care about the sins of a candidate’s son.
content: For President Biden and his party, the appointment of a special counsel on Friday in the investigation into Hunter Biden was hardly a welcome development. A blossoming criminal inquiry focused on the president’s son is a high-risk proposition that comes with the dangers of an election-year trial and investigations that could balloon beyond the tax and gun charges the younger Mr. Biden already faces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: U.S. Suicide Deaths Rose in 2022, C.D.C. Estimates Say
description: Provisional data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show that deaths by suicide were up last year — but not for all groups.
content: The estimated number of suicide deaths in the United States rose to nearly 50,000 in 2022, according to provisional data released on Thursday from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The total would be an increase of approximately 2.6 percent since 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadie Stein
title: Purging Books, Making Art and Ruling Chicago
description: An editor recommends two escapist biographies.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: FEMA’s Support for Maui Will Likely Be Closely Watched
description: The agency has been criticized for slow responses to major disasters in the past.
content: The Federal Emergency Management Agency has deployed teams, including search dogs, to Maui and Oahu to help local officials with search-and-rescue missions, emergency communications, logistics and coordination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Where’s the Vicuña Outrage?
description: Three men walk into a courtroom, as August heats up.
content: WASHINGTON — For a quiet summer Friday, there was quite a cacophony. Donald Trump crashing around. Clarence Thomas cashing in. Hunter Biden spinning out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: A survivor made a desperate dash into the sea to escape an inferno.
description: Direction from a Good Samaritan helped get a group of trapped residents to a safe spot.
content: Lisa Francis was trying to drive home from her job at a bank in Lahaina when the firestorm caught up to her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Trump Election Interference Case to Go to Grand Jury in Georgia Early Next Week
description: Atlanta-area prosecutors have indicated that they will go before a grand jury early next week to present the results of their investigation into election interference by former President Donald J. Trump and his allies, raising the possibility that within days Mr. Trump could face a fourth criminal indictment.
content: Atlanta-area prosecutors have indicated that they will go before a grand jury early next week to present the results of their investigation into election interference by former President Donald J. Trump and his allies, raising the possibility that within days Mr. Trump could face a fourth criminal indictment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Jump, In a Way
description: Rachel Fabi and Christina Iverson take flight with a sparkling Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — As I always say (when I’m talking about 15-Across), what goes around comes around. Or is it vice versa? Either way, it’s wonderful to see Rachel Fabi back, in collaboration with Christina Iverson. This is a really strong puzzle, richly clued and full of debuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: The Maui fires are more deadly than Hawaii’s 1960 tsunami.
description: Officials have warned that the confirmed death toll, 80 as of Friday night, would rise as responders begin entering hundreds of charred buildings.
content: Officials warn that the confirmed death toll from the Maui fires, 80 as of Friday night, will rise as responders begin entering the hundreds of charred buildings in Lahaina. But the fires have already taken more lives than a 1960 tsunami that killed 61 on the island of Hawaii, also known as the Big Island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart and Adrienne Grunwald
title: Romance Readers Swoon for Brooklyn’s Newest Bookstore
description: The Ripped Bodice opened in Park Slope to an engaged fan base with hearts in their eyes.
content: At 10 a.m. on a recent Saturday, a line of nearly 50 people — mostly women — stretched down a busy block in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Their eyes were on a pink-painted storefront adorned with pink balloons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Edgar Sandoval
title: 3-Year-Old Migrant Dies During Trip to Chicago on Bus Sponsored by Texas
description: The death appeared to be the first linked to Gov. Greg Abbott’s program of sending migrants from the border to Democratic-run cities.
content: A 3-year-old child died while traveling on a bus chartered by the state of Texas as it transported asylum seekers from the border city of Brownsville to Chicago as part of Gov. Greg Abbott’s program to send migrants from Texas to Democratic-run cities in other states, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Hawaii’s Governor Orders a Review of Whether Warning Systems Worked Properly
description: “We will do all that we can to find out how to protect our people more going forward,” said Gov. Josh Green.
content: Gov. Josh Green of Hawaii said on Friday that he had authorized a review of the emergency response to the devastating fires that decimated the town of Lahaina, even as he said that unusually powerful winds and fast-moving flames had complicated the effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Growing Segregation by Sex in Israel Raises Fears for Women’s Rights
description: Ultra-Orthodox members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s far-right coalition want to expand the powers of all-male rabbinical courts, and to bar women and men from mixing in many public arenas.
content: The trains from Tel Aviv were packed one evening last month when Inbal Boxerman, a 40-year-old mother of two, was blocked by a wall of men as she tried to board. One of them told her that women were not allowed on — the car was for men only.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Ukraine Makes ‘Tactically Significant’ Progress in Its Counteroffensive
description: Troops advanced 10 to 12 miles along two main lines of attack in Kyiv’s drive to reach the southern coast and sever Russian supply lines, while explosions echoed at the vital Kerch Strait Bridge.
content: After months of inching through minefields, villages and open steppes in grueling combat, Ukrainian forces are making somewhat bigger advances along two major lines of attack, according to analysts, Ukrainian officials and Russian military bloggers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Australia Outlasts France on Penalties, and the Host Nation Exhales
description: Australia needed 10 rounds of penalty kicks to confirm its place in the team’s first semifinal, and extend its country’s wild ride.
content: By the time it was over — three frazzling, agonizing, exhausting hours later — the feeling around the Brisbane Stadium was not so much delight or euphoria or even relief, but a sort of dizziness. Not vertigo from the heights that Australia have now ascended, but something closer to nausea, from the winding, coiling road that took the host nation up into the clouds.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: It Tasted Like Nothing, but the Fervor Around a Japanese Candy Was Everything
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 12, 2023.
content: “I asked myself: Why do you pay for this product? The answer is maybe to put myself into a state of ‘nothingness.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Great Britain is Beautiful. It’s Also Decaying.
description: It’s become difficult to build anywhere in the U.K.
content: “I feel somehow / That it isn’t going to last,” Philip Larkin wrote in “Going, Going,” his lament for the English countryside — that development would soon cover everything green and pleasant on his isle:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 12, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 12, 2023.
content: An article on Tuesday about the International Puppet Fringe Festival misstated the end date for “Myths, Legends and Spectacle: Puppets and Masks of Ralph Lee.” It will end on Aug. 13, not Aug. 31.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Downes
title: After the Shock and Grief, Hawaii Will Reinvent Itself Again
description: Like other island dots in our rising oceans, Hawaii is unusually imperiled and must do something about planetary crisis.
content: The disaster that erased the beloved West Maui town of Lahaina this week comes with the bitter taste of bewilderment. Brush fires met high winds whipped by a far-off hurricane, and overnight a historic town was gone, a pile of smoke and ashes. A lush watercolor landscape is redrawn in gray and black. At least 55 people are dead, and many more are missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle and Jan Hoffman
title: What the Supreme Court’s Decision to Hear the Purdue Pharma Case Means
description: A federal appeals court had signed off on a deal that would shield members of the wealthy Sackler family from lawsuits in exchange for billions for those harmed by the opioid epidemic.
content: The Supreme Court announced on Thursday that it would pause a bankruptcy deal for Purdue Pharma that would give billions of dollars to those harmed by the opioid epidemic in exchange for shielding members of the wealthy Sackler family from additional opioid-related lawsuits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Enid Nemy
title: Joan Kaplan Davidson, Philanthropist Who Championed New York, Dies at 96
description: As president of a foundation established by her father, she focused her grant making on issues related to the city’s architecture, design and quality of life.
content: Joan Kaplan Davidson, a preservationist and philanthropist who set projects in motion that upgraded the quality of life in New York City, died on Friday in Hudson, N.Y. She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien and Chris Buckley
title: As a Taiwanese Presidential Contender Visits U.S., He Tries to Walk a Fine Line
description: An outspoken critic of Beijing, Lai Ching-te aims to reassure voters and Washington that he will be a safe pair of hands if elected.
content: Vice President Lai Ching-te of Taiwan rose to prominence as a pugnacious opponent of Beijing’s claims over the island. But now, as a leading candidate in Taiwan’s presidential race, he is likely to present a more muted persona when he visits the United States starting Saturday. Expect restraint, not rousing speeches, Taiwanese officials and scholars say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard, Gulsin Harman and Ivor Prickett
title: In Istanbul, Revered Shrines Receive the Wishes and Woes of a Modern City
description: Turkey’s largest city is dotted with the tombs of religious figures, where pilgrims seek divine intervention. “When you ask for something from God, those who are beloved by God can be a go-between.”
content: Years ago, when her sister was diagnosed with ovarian cancer, Mahire Turk sought divine intervention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: Married During the 2003 Blackout
description: Couples who married during the widespread power outage reflect on their chaotic but fulfilling wedding days as they approach their 20th anniversaries.
content: It was shortly after 4 p.m. on a sweltering, sunny Thursday — Aug. 14, 2003 — when the power went out in eight states across the Northeast and Midwest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Scheck and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Zelensky Called Him a Criminal. Now Ukraine Calls Him for Guns and Ammo.
description: In its hunt for weapons, Ukraine has rolled back anticorruption rules and turned to people once seen as relics of an anything-goes era.
content: In the early weeks of the war in Ukraine, with the invading Russian Army bearing down on Kyiv, the Ukrainian government needed weapons, and quickly. So its Ministry of Defense made a desperate and unlikely phone call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and Glenn Thrush
title: Inexpensive Add-on Spawns a New Era of Machine Guns
description: Popular devices known as “switches” are turning ordinary pistols into fully automatic weapons, making them deadlier and a growing threat to bystanders.
content: Caison Robinson, 14, had just met up with a younger neighbor on their quiet street after finishing his chores when a gunman in a white car rolled up and fired a torrent of bullets in an instant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Use Your Noodle
description: Manaal Mohammed, a member of the 2023 New York Times Diverse Crossword Constructor Fellowship, makes an al dente debut.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

title: Are the Elite Anti-Trumpers the ‘Bad Guys’?
description: Readers react to David Brooks’s suggestion that the elite are partly to blame for Trumpism.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni, Michael J. de la Merced and Sarah Kessler
title: The Latest Trend on Yachts? Submersibles.
description: Only boats at least 120 feet long can hold a sub, which typically costs between $2 million to $7 million. Manufacturers of the deep-sea vessels say many of their clients are wealthy enthusiasts.
content: Charles Kohnen, co-founder of the submersible manufacturer SEAmagine Hydrospace, estimates that there are 200 manned vessels worldwide. Some are used by scientific institutions, others for tourism. But a growing number belong to a select group of yacht owners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Making a Boisterous Entrance, Trump Steals Spotlight in Iowa
description: The former president made his presence known when his private plane flew almost directly above the fairgrounds on Saturday. He spent the day needling his leading rival, Gov. Ron DeSantis.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump has made it known that he will not concede even a moment of the spotlight to his 2024 rivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Long-Shot Vivek Ramaswamy Says He Has a 50 percent Chance at Presidency
description: Despite polling in the mid-single digits, the biotech mogul projected outsize confidence at the Iowa State Fair.
content: Vivek Ramaswamy is not a man who wants for confidence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: John Barrett, Hair Stylist for the Fashionable Elite, Dies at 66
description: His salon on the penthouse level of Bergdorf Goodman drew regulars like Martha Stewart, Princess Diana, Ethel Kennedy and Hillary Clinton.
content: John Barrett, a hair dresser whose relaxed wit, scissor-sharp style and long line of A-list clients put him literally on top of the luxury fashion world, with a salon spanning the penthouse level of the Bergdorf Goodman department store, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 66.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Cote
title: Why a Floating Speck of Metal Sent Scientists’ Hearts Racing
description: For a few weeks, we had a taste of what it would be like if people cared about science as much as baseball.
content: The past three weeks have witnessed the dramatic rise and fall of a new candidate for the holy grail of materials science: a superconductor that works at room temperature. On July 22, a team of researchers in South Korea reported their findings on a compound they called LK-99, claiming that its discovery was a “brand new historical moment” that would “open a new era for mankind.” A boisterous frenzy of online physics discussions and rapid-fire publications followed, only to fall flat two weeks later. LK-99, it seemed, was a bust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, Aug. 5-11
description: This week, Spelling Bee players chose to quit to get ahead.
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: Rats in the Walls, Baby on the Way
description: It’s never a good time for a rodent infestation. But now?
content: I was splayed out on the brown couch, eating my daily (OK, twice daily) mint chocolate chip Popsicle, imagining his birth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hahna Yoon
title: At Asian Weddings, Cash Is King
description: Forget registries — in Asia, it is common to give marrying couples envelopes of cash. But unwritten rules on how much to give depend on who you are and which superstitions you believe.
content: When I received a wedding invitation from my friends Jiyeon Kim and Olof Norlander this year, I knew exactly where I would pick up their wedding present: the bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: U.S. Sunscreen Is Stuck in the ’90s. Is This a Job for Congress?
description: For years, American consumers have had to look abroad if they want the latest in sunscreen innovations. Some, including Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, think it’s time to revisit F.D.A. approval procedures.
content: After months of prompting, I have finally managed to help my husband form a daily sunscreen habit. Whenever I see traces of paper white cream in his dark beard, I think, We’re halfway there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman
title: Republicans Wanted a Special Counsel Investigation of Hunter Biden. Now Many Oppose It.
description: Although some G.O.P. lawmakers see the appointment of David C. Weiss as a vindication of their strategy, others criticize the now-scuttled plea deal he struck with Mr. Biden.
content: Congressional Republicans have for months repeatedly written to Attorney General Merrick B. Garland demanding he appoint a special counsel to investigate Hunter Biden, the president’s son, over his business dealings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Why an Unremarkable Racist Enjoyed the Backing of Billionaires
description: Like many supremacist ideologues before him, Richard Hanania benefited from elite sponsorship.
content: In 1923, Princeton University Press published “A Study of American Intelligence” by Carl Campbell Brigham, a eugenicist and professor of psychology at the university.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Tom Jones, Half of Record-Setting ‘Fantasticks’ Team, Dies at 95
description: He wrote the book and lyrics to a little show that opened in 1960 in Greenwich Village and became “the longest-running musical in the universe.”
content: Tom Jones, who wrote the book and lyrics for a modest musical called “The Fantasticks” that opened in 1960 in Greenwich Village and ran for an astonishing 42 years, propelled in part by its wistful opening song, “Try to Remember,” died on Friday at his home in Sharon, Conn. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aidan Gardiner
title: ‘These Old Guys?’ Short on Lifeguards, New York City Finds New Recruits
description: Among the rookie recruits monitoring New York’s pools, at least four were born in the Eisenhower administration. But they all passed the notorious lifeguard test, and the city needs them.
content: It was late afternoon at the pool in the Jesse Owens Playground in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn, and the heat had climbed into the mid-80s. Children, some in bold pink neon swimwear and others in white cotton tank tops, streamed into the water. It wasn’t long before splash battles broke out. Laughter mixed with the thumping music from a block party outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: A ‘Perfect Marriage’ Between Team and Player
description: Jason Heyward is on a winning club, has been reunited with Freddie Freeman and is having fun playing baseball again. The Dodgers are loving every minute.
content: The harmonic convergence between the resurrected Jason Heyward and the rampaging Los Angeles Dodgers crystallized beautifully one evening in Baltimore last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Dwyane Wade Was Destined for the Hall of Fame — and Politics?
description: Wade, the former Miami Heat guard, will cap his basketball career with a Hall of Fame induction this weekend. Some are hoping his next phase is as a political star.
content: When the Miami Heat selected Dwyane Wade with the fifth pick of the 2003 N.B.A. draft, the league was in dire need of star players to carry it out of the Michael Jordan era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Keith Waldrop, Professor and Award-Winning Poet, Dies at 90
description: He won the National Book Award for poetry in 2009, having first been nominated 40 years earlier. He taught at Brown University for four decades.
content: Keith Waldrop, whose first poetry collection was a finalist for a National Book Award in 1969 and who won the award 40 years later with his “Transcendental Studies: A Trilogy,” died on July 27. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: K2 Climbers Criticized Over Continuing Ascent After Finding Dying Porter
description: One of the climbers, Kristin Harila, said she continued her summit of the mountain after finding a porter who fell from a cliff and later died.
content: A Norwegian climber defended her decision to continue a record-breaking series of climbs last month after encountering an injured porter who later died during her ascent of K2, the second-highest mountain in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: A Withering Assessment of a Multibillion-Dollar Real Estate Windfall
description: Ontario’s auditor general found that the process to open up land in Toronto’s Greenbelt was influenced by and favored two developers.
content: When my colleague Norimitsu Onishi wrote about the matter early this year, there was a lot of suspicion, but little firm evidence, of undue development industry influence surrounding the process that led Doug Ford, Ontario’s premier, to open up the Greenbelt around Toronto to housing construction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: In the Shadow of More Fiery Rivals, Pence Leans Into Civility Politics
description: The former vice president met with Christian leaders and spoke about his respect for a late Democratic congressman despite their political differences.
content: Looking to contrast himself with former President Donald J. Trump and Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida — leading rivals in the race for the Republican nomination who converged on Iowa on Saturday — former Vice President Mike Pence made a play for civility politics during a round table with about two dozen Christian college and university presidents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen Early to ‘This American Life’: Day at the Beach
description: A Sedaris family reunion, a visit to Dr. Tequila and more stories from the surf and sand.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling and provides news, depth and serendipity. It is available to Times news subscribers on iOS. If you haven’t already, download the app here and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Walther
title: The Ultimate Horror Movie Is Really About Heaven and Hell
description: Spiritual lessons from “The Exorcist.”
content: It is one of those strange accidents of history that the best film ever made about the Roman Catholic Church was directed by a Jewish agnostic. The career of William Friedkin, who died on Monday at 87, spanned seven decades, but to the end of his life, his best-known picture remained “The Exorcist,” a horror movie from 1973 about a demonically possessed girl whose mother enlists two Catholic priests to save her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: With an Array of Tactics, Conservatives Seek to Oust Progressive Prosecutors
description: In Florida, Gov. Ron DeSantis suspended a second prosecutor. In Texas, activists are trying a new way to get rid of D.A.s they dislike.
content: When he was elected district attorney in Nueces County in 2016, Mark A. Gonzalez stood out even among a growing class of progressive Democratic prosecutors: a former criminal defense attorney with tattoos across his body, including one reading “Not Guilty,” whose name appeared in a Texas state police database of registered gang members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Lisa Lerer
title: The Iowa State Fair Saw Many G.O.P. Candidates but Only One Trump
description: Donald J. Trump asserted his dominance in Iowa on Saturday as he squared off against his closest rival, Ron DeSantis, in the Super Bowl of retail politics.
content: The crowd cheered. The pork was charred. And then someone shouted at former President Donald J. Trump, asking him to identify his biggest challenger in the 2024 Republican primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: My Neighbor Died. Now Her Empty House Is Breeding Rats. What Can I Do?
description: The situation potentially involves several city agencies, but you can start by filling out a complaint through 311.
content: Q: My family lives in a brownstone in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Our next-door neighbor passed away in July 2021 and didn’t leave a will. Her niece and nephew claim to be the inheritors of the home, though they say it’s still in court. Last December, a pipe burst in their house and both our houses flooded. Our insurance covered the repairs in our home, but the neighbor’s home is now filled with wet junk, and the stench is awful. Also, we now have a rat problem that an exterminator says is coming from the neighbor’s backyard. What recourse do we have here?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Move or Quit: Grindr Dictates New Office Rules Amid Union Drive
description: Two weeks after employees filed to organize, the company told some they had to change cities or would lose their jobs. It said the plan had long been in the works.
content: Quinn McGee learned last week that to keep their job as a product manager at Grindr, the gay dating app, they would have to move to California from New York by October under the company’s new return-to-office rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan W. Rosen
title: A Hotbed of Distance Running Talent Emerges in Uganda
description: Led by a duo of world-record holders, athletes from Uganda’s Mount Elgon are challenging decades of Kenyan and Ethiopian dominance.
content: With a mile to go in the 2017 World Cross Country Championships, Joshua Cheptegei had one thing on his mind: win gold for his country on home soil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
title: Pakistan Names Caretaker Prime Minister, Paving Way for Elections
description: The announcement comes amid growing speculation that elections — once expected to happen this fall — will be delayed until 2024.
content: The Pakistani government named a caretaker prime minister on Saturday, a move that kicks off preparations for the country’s next general elections and comes amid a year of political turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: England, Bruised but Unbowed, Reaches World Cup Semifinals
description: The Lionesses, champions of Europe, rallied past Colombia but now face yet another hurdle: a semifinal with host Australia on Wednesday.
content: England entered the World Cup knockout stages still waiting to look like the dominant team it had hoped it could be. Sure, England had yet to lose a game — an accomplishment during this chaotic tournament — but so far its performances had seemed a few rungs short of the level required to accomplish its goals: to reach its first final, to lift the World Cup trophy for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: At the Iowa State Fair, DeSantis Can’t Seem to Catch a Break
description: The Florida governor was hoping to have the stage to himself, but Donald Trump and his supporters have made that hard to achieve.
content: It’s been said that a bad day at the fair is always better than a good day at work. For Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, those two ideas collided on Saturday in Iowa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: As Hollywood Strikes Roll On, Viewers Have a Chance to Catch Up
description: After years of being inundated with new shows, some are using a pause in production to finally watch all the stuff they missed when it came out.
content: With Hollywood’s labor disputes grinding on, and virtually all production stopped, anxiety began creeping into Zain Habboo’s house in Chevy Chase, Md.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge F. Kovaleski
title: West Maui Had Been Warned It Was at High Risk for Wildfires
description: A report prepared for Maui County in 2020 detailed potential problems.
content: A hazard mitigation plan prepared for Maui County in 2020 said that the area of West Maui — where Lahaina is located — had the highest annual probability for wildfires of all the communities in the county.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen Doll
title: A Rollicking Tragicomic Tale of Unending Family Drama
description: In Paul Murray’s new novel, “The Bee Sting,” an Irish family faces economic ruin after the 2008 financial crash. And that’s just the start of their troubles.
content: In Paul Murray’s latest novel, “The Bee Sting” — an epic tale reaching back decades and spanning roughly 650 pages — things are pretty apocalyptic for one down-on-their-luck family, and that’s before we get to climate change. The problems, you might say, are coming from inside the house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Michael Corkery
title: After the Maui Fires, Locals Fear Being Shut Out of Recovery
description: Hawaii has long endured battles for resources among developers, tourists, Natives and workers. Now, many who lost homes and jobs wonder if there will be a place for them in Lahaina.
content: For years, Lahaina has had everything that makes Hawaii special: sweeping views of the Pacific, a charming main street and a rich cultural heritage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Heat, golfers and other obstacles to birding success
description: Readers describe some of the challenges to bird-watching.
content: We asked readers what hurdles you have encountered while birding. Whether you are experienced or new to the activity, have you had any stumbling blocks that made you think twice about continuing? Respond in the comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: Wedding Season, Disrupted
description: Lessons from the largest blackout in American history.
content: Wedding planning can be both joyous and perilous. The stakes can be high and much can go wrong (food poisoning, canceled flights, a poorly timed revelation of an affair).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathan Gelgud
title: Fassbinder’s World: A Refuge for Outcasts
description: Rethinking the German filmmaker’s vast body of work while reading a new book about him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Baratunde Thurston Eats His Feelings (With Ice Cream)
description: The host and executive producer of “America Outdoors With Baratunde Thurston” talks about revolutionary librarians, vibe-setting music and the city he thinks is underestimated.
content: The writer and cultural critic Baratunde Thurston wasn’t exactly a shoo-in for the PBS nature series that now bears his name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Cook Escobar, K.K. Rebecca Lai and Elena Shao
title: Mapping the Wildfire Destruction in Lahaina
description: In an analysis of satellite imagery, The Times identified about 1,900 structures that had been visibly damaged or destroyed by the blaze.
content: In an analysis of satellite imagery, The Times identified about 1,900 structures that had been visibly damaged or destroyed by the blaze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent McDonald, Emily Rhyne, Meg Felling and Nailah Morgan
title: Iowa State Fair Goers Weigh In on a Possible Trump-Biden Rematch
description: Lisa Lerer, a national political correspondent for The New York Times, spoke to voters about their options in the 2024 presidential election.
content: Lisa Lerer, a national political correspondent for The New York Times, spoke to voters about their options in the 2024 presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker, Rebecca Suner and Quincy Dein
title: New York Times Correspondent Reports on the Wildfires in Maui
description: Mike Baker, the Seattle bureau chief for The New York Times, visited Lahaina, Hawaii, where raging wildfires have decimated the area.
content: Mike Baker, the Seattle bureau chief for The New York Times, visited Lahaina, Hawaii, where raging wildfires have decimated the area.
source.name: The New York Times
